docs.lead_paragraph: Do you see yourself performing in a Vegas nightclub act? Would you rather meet people or read a book? Does driving give you a feeling of power?

headline.main: Trying to Get A Job? Check Yes or No; Tests Are Becoming Common in Hiring

docs.abstract: Job applicants across nation increasingly face taking a psychological test as part of hiring process; companies large and small are turning to psychological tests, developed by virtually unregulated test-publishing industry, to try to determine who is too impulsive, who falls short in integrity department or who is too self-absorbed to make the cut; companies are using tests to weed out undesirable applicants, even for entry-level jobs; some sample questions cited (M)
docs.snippet: Do you see yourself performing in a Vegas nightclub act?    Would you rather meet people or read a book?     Does driving give you a feeling of power?

docs.lead_paragraph: The managed-care industry has had better years. It is bad enough that doctors and hospitals are clamoring for higher fees, big employers are holding fast in their demands for rock-bottom prices, states are passing restrictive laws and stock traders are punishing companies whose profits do not take double-digit leaps. Now, adding to all those woes, baby boomers are revolting against the strictures of managed care. The generation that has set the social and political agendas of the nation for the last three decades is beginning to suffer the aches and pains of middle age. To win them over, H.M.O.'s are loosening the rules for those willing to pay a premium, thereby slowing a trend that just a couple of years ago seemed unstoppable.

headline.main: Baby Boomers Force New Rules for H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Baby boomers are revolting against strictures of managed care as they begin to suffer aches and pains of middle age, forcing health maintenance organizations to loosen rules for those willing to pay premium and slowing trend that few years ago seemed unstoppable; as many turn 50 in era of consumer empowerment, they are taking charge of their health care, consulting doctors and second-guessing doctors more often, and choosing their own medicines and other therapies; states are beginning to reflect their political power by enacting hundreds of new restrictions on way HMO's limit care, and Congress is preparing to debate bipartisan proposals for health-care bill of rights that would force companies to be more flexible; insurers claim new laws can only push up cost of health care; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House is debating ways to extend health coverage to three million ''near elderly,'' between the ages of 55 and 64, who are too young to qualify for Medicare. The Clinton Administration is right to try to help a vulnerable group. But the financial and political risks are steep. Many of the near elderly are early retirees and unhealthy, which means they would be costly to insure. Worse, once government coverage exists, employers who already provide health benefits to early retirees will cut back. In addition, the least healthy 55-to-65-year-olds will be tempted to retire once government promises to pick up the slack. The costs to Washington could soar.
docs.abstract: Editorial on Clinton Administration's debate over extending health-care coverage to three million Americans in so-called 'near elderly' class, between ages of 55 and 64, who are too young for Medicare and lack private insurance; suggests starting with smaller steps, as with children's program

docs.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the real estate recession of the early 90's, new owners have emerged in downtown Brooklyn to instill vigor into older office buildings near Court Street. Some of the buildings had been financed with mortgages that proved too generous for rent and occupancy levels in the 90's to sustain. Others lost big tenants and were no longer attractive investments for their owners. Whatever the cause, properties changed hands and new owners have been putting money into them to strengthen their competitive position in the improved market of the last two years.

headline.main: Commercial Real Estate; In Brooklyn, New Allure For Old Office Buildings

docs.abstract: Article contends that in aftermath of real estate recession of early 90's, new owners have emerged in downtown Brooklyn to instill vigor into older office buildings near Court Street; examples cited; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The effort to unionize 10,000 New York City limousine drivers has received a boost from the National Labor Relations Board, which ruled that the drivers are not independent contractors, as management insisted, but are instead employees with the right to join a union. The International Association of Machinists, which is overseeing the effort to unionize the drivers, announced the labor board's decision yesterday and also announced that 500 drivers at Elite Limousine Plus, one of the city's largest black-car companies, had voted to join the union. The vote was 218 to join the union and 117 against.

headline.main: Government Ruling Paves Way for Limousine Drivers' Union

docs.abstract: Effort to unionize 10,000 New York City limousine drivers receives boost from National Labor Relations Board, which rules that drivers are not independent contractors, as management insisted, but are instead employees with right to join union; International Assn of Machinists is overseeing unionization efforts (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 5 the other morning, Marlene Garrett had her 11-month-old baby in her arms and was guiding her other two sleep-dazed children, ages 3 and 4, through the darkness to the baby sitter's. ''Mama has to go to work so she can buy you shoes,'' Mrs. Garrett told them. She had just that day moved up the economic ladder, from a job selling sneakers for $5.25 an hour to a job behind the counter at a bagel cafe for $6 an hour. Her shift started at 6, and she did not want to be late.

headline.main: Children of Working Poor Are Day Care's Forgotten

docs.abstract: Low-income working families are, in many ways, forgotten class in national debate over child care; are too poor to afford nanny or part-time work; many make too much to qualify for government programs; others make little enough to qualify, but are low on long waiting lists while priority is given to women leaving welfare rolls for jobs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having succeeded in extending health care coverage to millions of children, the White House and some members of Congress are now turning attention to another group of uninsured Americans -- the 3 million who are 55 to 64 years old. The people in this age group, called the ''near elderly,'' are too young for Medicare, the insurance program for those 65 and older, and not poor enough for Medicaid, the program for the indigent and disabled. Many have chronic illnesses like diabetes, high blood pressure, ulcers and bladder and kidney ailments that require extensive and costly care.

headline.main: 55-TO-64 BRACKET SEEMS NEXT IN LINE FOR INSURANCE AID

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration and some members of Congress weigh steps to aid some 3 million Americans aged 55 to 64 years old who do not have health insurance; many of 'nearly elderly,' who are too young for Medicare and not poor enough for Medicaid, have chronic illnesses that require extensive and costly care; many lost jobs and health benefits in corporate downsizing this decade; Republican-led Congress seen likely to oppose new program (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton is preparing for another election-year battle over health care as he proposes sweeping new Federal regulations for insurance companies and health maintenance organizations to protect patients' rights. A Presidential advisory panel recommended last week a bill of rights for patients. But in urging Congress to translate the rights into law, Mr. Clinton went beyond the recommendations of the 34-member panel, which reserved judgment on who should enforce the proposed standards.

headline.main: Clinton Plans New Health Care Fight

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton prepares for another election-year battle over health care as he proposes sweeping new Federal rules for insurance companies and health maintenance organizations to protect patients' rights; Administration aides say they would welcome fight over issue, which they expect will unite Democrats and divide Republicans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 U.S. Says It Is Pressing Israeli Leader for Results The Clinton Administration is pressing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to produce results during talks with the Palestinians scheduled for December, senior American officials said. A1 Fighting Kills Nine in Lebanon Mortar attacks by Lebanese guerrillas in southern Lebanon killed nine Lebanese civilians, including a 7-year-old girl, according to Israeli officials. Intense exchanges of artillery, mortar and rocket fire between the guerrillas and Israeli troops during a weekend of heavy fighting also left two Israeli soldiers slightly wounded. A10
